Figures 3-5 show the variations in obtained and preferred mean values for the Max Planck RM’s (basaltic
glasses KL-2G and ML-3BG, andesite StHs6/80G and quartz diorite T-1G, komatiites GOR-128 and GOR- 132G). In these diagrams the observed errors are calculated for our obtained results compared with the preferred values for these materials cited in [17].
Variations diagrams for REE are presented in Figures 6-8 normalized with respect to the C1 chondrite [16] [17].
Figure 3 shows that most of the obtained values are placed between 85% and 115% of the expected mean values; the exception is Mo in KL-2G. The values obtained for the REE in basalts ML-3BG and KL-2G (Figure 6) are very close to the expected ones.
Some obtained values shown in Figure 4 are higher than the recommended figures cited for the medium to heavy REE and for Y, Zr, Mo and Ti in the quartz diorite T-1G, but lower than the recommended figures for Cr, Pb, Ni and Zn. These results may be caused by some tiny inhomogeneity of the reference material, locally con- centrating heavy REE and HFSE and diluting the concentration of elements like Cr, Pb, Ni, Zn and Sn, as shown by [18] for the RM ATHO-1G.
The obtained values compared with the expected ones for the andesite glass StHs6/80G are somewhat outside the limit of ±15% for the following elements: Li, Cr, Co, Ni, Cu, Ga, Rb, Mo and Cs. Chromium and Ni defi- ciencies are also observed in T-1G, possibly indicating calibration problems, other than inhomogeneous distribu- tion. The REE variation diagram, presented in Figure 7, shows that the obtained values for andesite StHs6/80G is very close to the expected values, while the medium to heavy REE in T-1G shows increased values.
In komatiite GOR-128 (Figure 5), the main elements showing diminished values in relation to the expected ones are Li, V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Rb, Mo, Cs, Pb, U. In sample GOR-132G (Figure 5) the same relation- ship is observed for elements Ni, Cu, Zn, Rb, Mo, Cs, Ce, Th and U. These elements show values that are very much increased or diminished when compared with NIST-612, which may not be the best calibration material to be used for this exercise. On the other hand, lack of homogeneity (see [19] and [20]) may be another explanation, possibly caused by quench crystallization of olivine, which could sequester some elements. A larger set of ana- lytical data, not restricted to our limited number of determinations, is needed. The REE variation diagrams pre- sented in Figure 8 (komatiites) show that the obtained values are close to the certified values.
5. Conclusions The obtained values for the several reference materials made available by the USGS and the Max Planck Insti- tute cover a rather wide spectrum of elemental abundances for the over 40 elements determined with the LA-Q- ICPMS technique, the methodology used in this contribution.

The used technique provides high quality results, in terms of analytical accuracy, and is also very fast. The
samples can be prepared as thin sections, with a thickness of around 40 to 60 microns, or as mineral grains mounted within polished epoxy resins.
Interferences can be kept at minimum levels, a result achieved with the use of dry plasma, thereby diminish- ing the influence of agents such as present in aqueous acid systems (O2?, OH?, Cl?, 3NO
? , etc.). However, iso- topes such as 135Ba, 139La, 140Ce, and others may interfere on medium and heavy REE, even if the level of oxides is kept below the recommended value of 1%. Increased values of some REE may be caused by the generation of several spurious REE molecular species (e.g. [21]). The point is illustrated in Figure 6, where 155Gd may owe its increase to interference by 139La16O+. Careful selection of isotope species is therefore recommended, before re- lying on one or the other isotopes for analytical calibrations.

The rock glasses prepared by the Max Planck Institute cover an adequate spectrum of elements important for
studies in igneous petrology, but the materials seem to present a lack of homogeneity for some elements, de- pending on the analyzed mass and of the spot used for identification [15] and may therefore be the cause for the observed discrepancies in obtained results. More tests are certainly needed to test statistically this hypothesis, in order to certify these glasses as proper equivalents of the USGS materials.
The use of internal standards, especially MgO and CaO, is a necessary tool to standardize obtained results with our discussed technique. But many minerals may lack sufficient contents of CaO to be subjected to the LA- Q-ICPMS methodology, a fact that limits the scope of the glasses prepared by NIST, with low to very low MgO contents [22] [23]. Another factor to be considered is the possibility of fractionation of many elements, depend- ing on the used internal standard [24]. There is certainly a need to continue the search for an adequate prepara- tion of proper rock standards to be used for LA studies in minerals.

Abstract
Eight new in situ U-Pb zircon age determinations by Shrimp and LA-MC-ICPMS reveal
that the main granite magmatism in the São Roque Domain, which is largely dominated
by high-K calc-alkaline monzogranites with subordinate peraluminous leucogranites,
occurred between 604±3 and 591±4 Ma. Importantly, this small temporal range is ca.
20-30 Ma younger than previously admitted based on U-Pb TIMS dates from literature,
some of which obtained in the same occurrences now dated. The observed discrepancy
seems related to the presence of small Paleoproterozoic inherited cores in part of the
zircon populations used for TIMS dating, which could also respond for the unusually
high (up to 10 Ma) uncertainty associated with most of these ages. The younger age
range now identified for the São Roque granite magmatism has important implications
for the evolution of the Ribeira Fold Belt. Whilst previously admitted ages ca. 620-630
Ma substantiated correlations with the widespread and intensely foliated high-K calc-
alkaline granitoid rocks of the neighbor Socorro-Guaxupé Thrust Nappe (potentially
associated with an accretionary continental margin), the ~ 600-590 Ma interval seems
more consistent with a late deformation tectonic setting.
Strongly negative eHf(t) characterize the magmatic zircons from the São Roque Domain
granites. An eastward increase from -22 in the São Roque Granite to -11 in the
Cantareira Granite and neighboring stocks suggests an across-domain shift in granite
sources. Such eastward younging of sources, also indicated by Sm-Nd isotope data from
granites and supracrustal sequences in neighboring domains, is suggestive that some of
the first-order limits and discontinuities in this belt are not defined by the strike-slip
fault systems traditionally taken to separate distinct domains. Although the
negative eHf(t) and eNd(t) indicate sources with long crustal residence for all studied
granite plutons, the observed range is more radiogenic than the values calculated at 600
Ma for both the Mesoproterozoic (1.5-1.8 Ga) passive-margin metavolcano-sedimentary
sequences of the São Roque Domain and their inferred Archean to Paleoproterozoic

1. Introduction
The use of in situ techniques (Shrimp and LA-ICPMS) for U-Pb zircon dating
offers, besides the obvious advantages of simplified preparation procedures and speed
of analysis, the opportunity of avoiding crystal domains with evidence of inheritance or
late disturbance as an important bonus. Even though the achieved precision of both
techniques (typically 1% relative, or ± 5 Ma at ~600 Ma) does not permit to resolve
temporally events identified by field criteria in many individual plutonic bodies, in
some cases they may be advantageous over the more precise TIMS technique. In
particular, they allow obtain a large number of concordant ages in texturally-controlled
portions of the crystals that are fundamental to unambiguously identify true magmatic
crystallization ages. This is particularly true when determining the crystallization ages
of granitic rocks from some parts of the Ribeira Belt in SE Brazil, where previous TIMS
U-Pb zircon dating has revealed the frequent presence of inheritance (e.g., Janasi et al.,
2001; Prazeres Filho et al., 2003). In fact, the influence of inheritance may be too
difficult to avoid when multi-grain fractions or even single grains are used, which may
in practice result in imprecise and sometimes unreliable ages.
The São Roque Domain is a fault-bounded segment of the Ribeira Belt that
corresponds to the northern extension of the Apiaí Terrane, mostly composed of ~1.8-
1.4 Ga meta-volcanosedimentary sequences of rift and passive-margin character, which
were metamorphosed and intruded by large volumes of granite in the late
Neoproterozoic (Ediacaran). In this study, we selected seven among the most
representative granite plutons from the São Roque Domain to perform U-Pb zircon
dating by Shrimp and LA-ICPMS; some of them were previously dated by TIMS, but
the results remained unpublished and carry relatively high (8-12 Ma) uncertainties
(Topfner, 1996; Ragatky, 1998).
We also determined Hf isotope ratios in the same portions of crystals sampled
for U-Pb dating, thus pioneering the use of this isotope system for granites in this
domain. The Hf isotope system revealed a particularly useful tool for inferences on the
petrogenesis and tectonic significance of the São Roque granites, especially when
integrated with previous geological and geochemical studies, including whole-rock Sm-

2. Geological setting
2.1. The São Roque Domain in the tectonic framework of SE Brazil
The Ribeira Belt corresponds to the central segment of an extensive
Neoproterozoic orogenic system running roughly parallel to the present Atlantic
coastline from latitude 16 o S in Brazil to 35
o S in Uruguay. The northern ~N-S oriented
segment of this system from latitude 16 o to 21
o S is the Araçuaí Belt (Fig. 1) where,
after a series of Mesoproterozoic rifting episodes, a passive margin developed at the
eastern margin of a continental mass stabilized at ~2.05 Ga (the São Francisco craton).
After ca. 800 Ma, this evolved to an active margin with the closure of an ocean that lied
between the São Francisco and Congo cratons (Alkmim et al., 2006).
The continuity of a stable cratonic area west of the Ribeira and (south of latitude
27 o S) Dom Feliciano belts is less obvious, mostly due to cover by the extensive
Phanerozoic Paraná Sedimentary Basin (Fig. 1). Geophysical evidence has been used to
infer the presence of cratonic blocks beneath the Paraná Basin (the hidden
Paranapanema “craton” of Mantovani & Brito Neves, 2005, and the northern
continuation of the Rio de la Plata craton; Rapela et al., 2007). In many current tectonic
models, these “cratonic blocks” would have amalgamated to each other and to the São
Francisco Craton in earlier episodes of Neoproterozoic evolution, before accretion of
the eastern terrains of the Ribeira and Dom Feliciano belts.
The metavolcano-sedimentary sequences comprising the Ribeira Belt correspond
to passive margin deposits developed mostly from 1.8 to 1.4 Ga in the Apiaí Terrane
(Siga Jr. et al., 2011, Juliani et al., 2000), and possibly later in the eastern Embu
Terrane. Expressive magmatic arc terranes are recognized east of both the Ribeira Belt
(the Rio Negro arc; Tupinambá et al., 2012) and the Dom Feliciano Belt (the
Florianópolis-Pelotas batholith and African counterparts, Basei et al., 2005). Magmatic
arc activity and related plate convergence are inferred to have started as early as 800
Ma, and no discontinuity with arc systems associated with the Araçuaí Belt is described.
Moreover, evidence of expressive granite generation beginning at ca. 780 Ma is

The São Roque Domain (SRD) is one of several fault-bounded blocks that make
up the south Ribeira Belt, and represents the northeastern portion of the Apiaí Terrane
(Fig. 1; Campos Neto 2000; Heilbron et al., 2008). Our recent work on sedimentary
provenance in metasandstones from the SRD (Henrique-Pinto et al., 2014) indicates
source areas that are very similar to the São Francisco craton, leading to the suggestion
that the Apiaí Terrane corresponds to the SW extension of the eastearn passive margin
of the São Francisco Paleoplate, an interpretation that is consistent with gravity data
(Rocha 2009).
The SRD hosts meta-volcano-sedimentary sequences of dominantly
Mesoproterozoic ages (e.g., Hackspacher et al., 2000; Juliani et al., 2000; Henrique-
Pinto and Janasi, 2010) and is, like all other domains of the Ribeira Belt, intruded by
significant volumes of Neoproterozoic granites. The SRD is bordered to the north by the
Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe (SGN), an allochtonous high-grade terrane that exposes a large
(~20 km) vertical section of the Neoproterozoic crust also intruded by large volumes of
granites and whose origin is alternatively linked in the literature to the Brasilia or to the
Ribeira Belt.
2.2. Neoproterozoic granite magmatism in the São Roque Domain
Neoproterozoic granite magmatism is widespread and voluminous in the Ribeira
Belt and has been subject of several reviews in recent years (e.g., Janasi & Ulbrich,
1991; Heilbron et al., 2004). Most of the granites were generated in a<100 Ma time
interval (650-560 Ma), but significantly older and younger manifestations are reported
(e.g., ~750-800 Ma occurrences of orthogneiss from several domains, and the ~500 Ma
“G5” granites found only in the Costeiro Domain), expanding the whole history of
Neoproterozoic granitic magmatism to a range of as much as 300 Ma. It is well known,
on the other hand, that the age range of peak magmatism may be shorter within
individual domains, and shows a regional shift, with a general tendency to be younger
toward SE; this pattern is followed by the ages of the post-orogenic magmatism,
indicating progressive stabilization of the fold belt in this direction.

Granites from the SRD occur as a series of plutons whose shapes are often
strongly controlled by NE-directed transcurrent faults (Fig. 2), indicating that their
emplacement overlapped the development of the Ribeira Belt strike-slip tectonics. By
far the most typical granite type forming the largest plutons is a porphyritic biotite
monzogranite to granodiorite/quartz monzonite with K-feldspar megacrysts (2-4 cm in
length) set in a medium to coarse-grained matrix. The metaluminous character of these
granites is indicated by the presence of abundant accessory titanite; hornblende is
present in the more mafic samples, but may be rare in some occurrences. Chemically,
they are usually SiO2-poor, often straddling the limit between acid and intermediate
rocks (64-68% SiO2); relatively high mg# (35-45) and high K/Na are typical, thus
classifying as high-K calc-alkaline (HKCA) granites (Fig. 4). Other typical geochemical
signatures are fractionated REE patterns lacking significant negative Eu anomalies, high
contents of LILE (Ba= 1000-2000 ppm; Sr= 600-1000 ppm), and high Sr/Y (often >30).
A contribution from contemporaneous mafic magmatism is evident in some
occurrences, in the form of scattered mafic synplutonic dykes and mafic microgranular
enclaves. Often more evident are evidences of contamination by assimilation of
metasedimentary rocks, which may appear as xenoliths or strongly modified mica-rich
enclaves.
Two elongated plutons with subalkaline affinities occur at the westernmost
portion of the SRD, both showing locally the rapakivi texture, and considered in some
works as of post-orogenic character. The São Francisco Granite fits better into the
definition of A-type granites, as it is dominated by fractionated, high-SiO2 granites, with
low Sr (<100 ppm) and weakly fractionated REE patterns ((La/Yb)N= 12-15 with
strongly negative Eu anomalies (Eu/Eu*= 0.2-0.3) (Wernick et al., 1993; Godoy et al.,
2010). The Sorocaba Granite, with characteristic elongated shape, is constituted of
usually non-deformed more mafic porphyritic monzogranites; although chemically
distinct from the HKCA granites (e.g., <300 ppm Sr, moderately fractionated
((La/Yb)N= 15-20) REE patterns with negative Eu anomalies (Eu/Eu*= 0.4-0.6)) is of
more ambiguous affinity.
Other minor occurrences of subalkaline granite are known from the central
portion of the SRD, as late occurrences within the Cantareira Granite (the Canivete type
of Dantas, 1990) and the deformed Vila dos Remédios Quartz Syenite.
The Tico-Tico Granite is a small E-W elongated (7 x 1.5 km; area= 10 km 2 )
occurrence, but constitutes the largest pluton entirely composed of frankly peraluminous

A large number of medium-sized granite plutons of diverse composition occur at
the easternmost portion of the SRD (Igaratá region). These were grouped by Campos
Neto et al. (1983) in several suites, on the basis of variations in modal composition
(monzogranite to granodiorite/quartz monzonite, with small diorite bodies), mineralogy
(usually metaluminous to marginally peraluminous) and texture (porphyritic to
equigranular; foliated to massive). Geochemical and Sr-Nd isotope data for these
granites were presented by Ragatky (1998), and revealed predominance of high-K calc-
alkaline granites that, although in some cases are similar to the main plutons from the
central SRD, are commonly less Ba and Sr-rich and show more radiogenic Nd isotope
signatures (see below).
3. Methods
In situ isotope determinations in zircon by LA-MC-ICPMS and Shrimp aiming
to obtain space-resolved ages and Hf isotope ratios were the main tools used in this
work. The zircon crystals were extracted from 6-8 kg granite samples using standard
techniques of milling, magnetic and dense liquids concentration. Previously to the
microanalyses, cathodo-luminescence imagens were obtained from the epoxy mounts
with 50-100 crystals, and carefully studied to identify textural features of the zircon
crystals. Whole-rock major and trace-element data (by XRF and solution-ICPMS,
respectively) and Sr-Nd isotope data were obtained for samples chosen for our study, as
part of their characterization, and to allow comparison with literature data. All analyses
were performed in laboratories of the Instituto de Geociências, Universidade de São
Paulo, Brazil. Details of the analytical protocols of all methods employed are presented
in Supplementary File 1.

5. Zircon age and Hf isotope determinations
5.1. São Roque Granite
The westernmost studied pluton is the ~160 km 2 São Roque Granite, which has,
in plant, the rough shape of a triangle, with the base partly defined by the N70E-directed
Taxaquara Fault (Fig. 2).
The pluton was mapped in detail by Andrade et al. (1994) who recognized a
main unit of porphyritic hornblende-biotite monzogranite to granodiorite distributed
throughout the pluton (Fig. 3a). This unit is intruded by small occurrences of pink to
gray inequigranular biotite monzogranite whose distribution suggests a discontinuous
body of roughly half-ring shape at the pluton’s central/southeastern portion and by pink
medium-grained equigranular monzogranite with associated coarse-grained tourmaline-
muscovite granite at the pluton’s northern portion (Fig. 3a).

Sample SR-07 corresponds to the predominant porphyritic hornblende-biotite
monzogranite typical of the São Roque Granite, and was collected in a roadcut in the
Livio Tagliassachi Road (SP-053/280) close to the access to the Castelo Branco
Highway (UTM coordinates of all samples used in this study are listed in Tables 2-4;
full results of whole-rock geochemical analyses are in Supplementary File 2). A
chemical analysis shows that the granite is relatively primitive with 64% SiO2, 1.7%
MgO, 3.2% CaO, with high K2O (4.8%) and high K2O/Na2O (1.6) typical of a
metaluminous high-K calc-alkaline granitic rock. A moderately fractionated chondrite-
normalized REE pattern ((La/Yb)N= 29) with a weak negative Eu anomaly (Eu*/Eu=
0.8) (Fig. 5) and high Sr/Y (40) are typical.
Sample SR-05 is an inequigranular biotite granite collected in a roadcut 7 km to
the south of SR-07 along the same road. This granite has a much more evolved
composition with 75% SiO2, 0.2% MgO and 1.2% CaO, and shows a less fractionated
REE pattern *(La/Yb)N= 12) with lower LREE contents and well-defined negative Eu
anomaly (Eu*/Eu= 0.57); Sr/Y is lower (19). These features suggest that, if related to
the predominant São Roque granites, the magma that generated SR-05 resulted from
fractionation involving plagioclase and a LREE-bearing accessory mineral.
Zircon morphology and U-Pb dating
Zircon crystals from SR-07 are short (100-200 mm), with ~2:1 aspect ratio and
well developed oscillatory zoning. U contents are 600-1000 ppm (average 791 ppm), Th
350-900 ppm (average 609 ppm), and Th/U varies from 0.6 to 1.0 (average 0.76). An
exception is core 23.1, with extremely high Th (9000 ppm) U (4000 ppm), Th/U 2.5,
black in CL. Inherited core 18.1 (see below) has extremely low Th/U 0.02 due to Th ~3
ppm.
LA-ICPMS determinations were performed in 26 spots, and most are nearly
concordant (Table 2). With the exclusion of two inherited cores and two points with
larger errors, a concordia age is obtained from all remaining spots, and yields 602.6±3.8
Ma (2s; MSWD= 0.05, probability of concordance= 0.83; Fig. 7) as the best estimate of
the age of this granite.

5.2. Itaqui Granite and Fazenda Itahyê Stock
The Itaqui Granite is a 120 km 2 pluton elongated in the E-W direction,
extending over 24 km parallel to Taxaquara Fault, which defines its southern contact.
Wernick & Ferreira (1993), based on detailed mapping, recognized that the bulk of the
pluton was built in two main phases of intrusion.
The early phase consists of two units of hornblende-bearing porphyritic granitic
rocks with 2.5-3 cm K-feldspar megacrysts. The less voluminous and more
differentiated monzogranite unit (with CI~6; 68-69% SiO2; 0.8-0.9% MgO) occurs as a
<2 km-wide border wrapping the more primitive granodiorite unit (with CI~15; 64-65%
SiO2, 1.8-2.2% MgO) along the western half of the pluton where it attains its greater
width (up to 8 km) (Fig. 3b).
The late phase comprises two ellipsoidal stocks that intrude the previous units at
the southern portion of the pluton, and thus make up its southern contact over most of
its extension (Fig. 3b). Both are composed of inequigranular biotite monzogranites with
rare to absent K-feldspar megacrysts. The western stock (~10 x 4 km) is composed of
more primitive monzogranites (CI~9; 66-69% SiO2; 0.9-1.2% MgO) as compared to the
eastern stock (~5 x 2 km) (CI7; 69-70% SiO2; 0.5-0.8% MgO).
Both early and late phase Itaqui granites are characteristically high-K calc-
alkaline (metaluminous, with 3.7-4.4% K2O and K2O/Na2O= 1.3-1.0), with high Sr
(600-900 ppm) and Ba (1000-1900 ppm). Chondrite-normalized REE patterns are
typically fractionated with negligible Eu anomalies, typically with (La/Yb)N= 50-60 in
the compositionally intermediate Pedreira Cantareira and Aldeia da Serra units and 30-

The Fazenda Itahyê granitic stock is a small (<2 km 2 ) granite occurrence
located ~3,5 km to the NE of Itaqui, and is composed of non-foliated porphyritic
hornblende-biotite granodiorite in all mineralogical and geochemical aspects similar to
more primitive unit of the Itaqui Granite early phase (cf. Supplementary File 2).
Sample petrography and geochemistry
Samples ITQ-2 and ITQ-E from the Itaqui Granite were collected in the Polimix
quarry located at the central portion of the pluton (Fig. 3b). Apart from its lower K2O
(2.9%) and Ba (620 ppm), sample ITQ-2 is a typical porphyritic biotite monzogranite
from the more primitive early phase unit. Sample ITQ-E is a medium- to fine-grained
basic enclave with 50% SiO2 from the same quarry. Both samples have relatively high
mg# (0.43-0.46), Sr (~800 ppm), and fractionated REE patterns ((La/Yb)N=31 in ITQ-2
and 18 in the enclave, which has higher HREE contents) with nearly absent Eu
anomalies (Eu/Eu*= 0.89 and 0.97, respectively).
Sample MD-24 from the Fazenda Itahyê granite is a porphyritic hornblende-
biotite monzogranite; its chemical composition both in terms of major and trace-
elements is nearly identical to that of ITQ-2, apart from higher and more typical K2O
(4.3%) and Ba (1350 ppm) contents.
Zircon morphology and U-Pb dating
ITQ-2 crystals are 100-300 µm in length, with aspect ratio 2:1 to 4:1. Cores may
be unzoned or show oscillatory zoning; a few cores have convolute aspect; borders are
typically oscillatory zoned. Typical Th/U ratios are in the range 0.4-0.6 (average 0.44;
one exception with 1.1); average U is 537 ppm.
Sixteen points were analyzed, by Shrimp and show small discordance (Table 3).
A concordia age of 595.1±4.6 Ma (MSWD= 2.1; Fig. 8) was obtained from 12 points (4
were discarded because of high 204
Pb), and is interpreted as the crystallization age of
this sample.
ITQ-E crystals are all short, 2:1, but show two populations with equivalent
abundance: (1) crystals with oscillatory zoning, which may have light limpid cores in
CL images; (2) nearly homogeneously black crystals in CL images, which may reflect
high U cores; thin light rims are present in a few of these crystals.

The Hf isotope composition of zircons from sample ITQ-2 is relatively

5.3. Cantareira Granite and satellites
The Cantareira Granite is the largest granite occurrence in the São Roque
Domain, attaining batholithic dimensions (~360 km 2 ); an indentation of country rock
along its western-central portion indicates that the batholith shall correspond in reality
to the junction of two plutons (Fig. 3c).

The southern pluton, like the São Roque and Itaqui granites, has its southern
limit defined by the Taxaquara Fault, along which it extends for ca. 12 km; is has a
roughly circular shape in plant, being connected to the northern pluton by a bulge that
has a width of 2-4 km (Fig. 3c). It is mostly constituted of a porphyritic biotite
monzogranite not different from the predominant facies of the northern pluton.
The Taipas granitic stock is a small satellite (2 km 2 ) located immediately to the
west of the Cantareira Granite, in the region between the northern and southern plutons
(Fig. 3c). The main rock type is a porphyritic biotite monzogranite usually more felsic
than the typical Cantareira granite, but it is compositionally diverse, and a facies similar
to the typical Cantareira porphyritic biotite monzogranite is locally present.
The Perus tourmaline granites correspond to a series of small bodies of aplite-
pegmatite that occur in the neighborhood of Taipas and Cantareira northern pluton (Fig.
3c). These occurrences have attracted the attention of several researchers because of
their peculiar mineralogy, chemical composition (extremely fractionated; rich in several
incompatible elements as B, U and Rb) and structure (characteristically banded, with
alternating aplite and pegmatite bands) (Teupenheyer, 1994; Morteani et al., 2008).
Sample petrography and geochemistry
Sample CANT-6, collected in the Basalto quarry, located at the westernmost
portion of the northern Cantareira Granite, is a typical porphyritic biotite monzogranite.

coarse-grained syenogranite from the southern Cantareira Granite, and is
petrographically and chemically similar to the Canivete facies described by Dantas
(1990).
Sample TAP-1 from the Taipas stock was collected in the Pedreira Construcap, a
quarry located at the Av. Raimundo Pereira de Magalhães, Perus, close to the Basalto
quarry. It is a porphyritic biotite monzogranite with 2-3 cm K-feldspar megacrysts set in
a medium to coarse-grained matrx.

Zircon morphology and U-Pb dating
CANT-6 zircon crystals are 200-400 µm in length with aspect ratio 2:1 to 6:1.
Cores show oscillatory zoning; a few cores have convolute aspect; possible inherited

Twelve points from CANT-6 zircons were analysed by Shrimp, and most are
<10% discordant (Table 3). Six points define a coherent age group, and allow obtain a

younger 206

Pb or

Pb/ 238
U

5.4. Vila dos Remédios foliated quartz syenite
Sample JP-18 is an inequigranular coarse-grained quartz syenite with well-
developed foliation collected in a roadcut in the Fernão Dias Highway. The Vila dos
Remédios quartz syenite is metaluminous, and characterized by very low mg# (10),
high Zr (> 400 ppm), K/Na and Ba/Sr (~10) (Dantas, 1990), features that are more akin
to a within-plate geochemical signature.
Zircon morphology and U-Pb dating
Zircon crystals from JP18 show wide variations in shape, with aspect ratios 2:1
to 5:1, and lengths up to 300 mm (Supplementary File 3). CL images show white,
homogeneous elongated cores in many of the crystals with greater aspect ratios; thin
dark rims are present in a few crystals, mantling an inner zone with oscillatory zoning.
LA-ICPMS analyses yield concordant results, but these spread over the
concordia over a large time range (636-510 Ma). The five points with ages lower than
570 Ma were discarded from regressions since they seem to correspond to regions
disturbed by the presence of inclusions or are otherwise too diverse from the main
population. Four CL-bright homogeneous cores yield the oldest ages, and are
interpreted as antecrysts; a regression from these points results in a concordia age of
630.5 ±8.0 Ma (MSWD= 0.045). Two other crystals with inherited cores were analyzed
(20.1 and 22.1), but apparently the analyses included portions of younger rims, lowering
the dates. Regression of the remaining 13 analyses, mostly from rims and cores with
oscillatory zoning, resulted in a concordia age of 591.2 ±3.4 Ma (MSWD= 2.1), which
is considered the best estimate of the magmatic crystallization age of this sample.

6. Discussion
6.1. Age of granitic magmatism in the São Roque Domain
In this study, we have chosen for in situ U-Pb dating some of the typical and
most expressive granite plutons from the SRD (Cantareira, Itaqui, São Roque). These
are all predominantly formed by a similar rock type (high K, high Ba-Sr porphyritic
(Hbl)-Bt monzogranite to granodiorite of metaluminous character, showing fractionated
REE patterns with negligible Eu negative anomalies and high Sr/Y). To have a more
complete sampling of the SRD granites, however, we also dated the most expressive
occurrence of peraluminous leucogranites forming and independent pluton (Tico-Tico
Granite) and granites with a subalkaline character, forming and independent pluton
(Vila dos Remédios Quartz Syenite) or a small intrusive bodies within the Cantareira
Granite (sample MD-42b).
All magmatic crystallization ages obtained here are within a small time range
(from 604±3 to 591±4 Ma), independently of rock type. Taken separately, the high-K
calc-alkaline granites are within an even smaller time range (604-595 Ma), and the ages
obtained for the main rock type of the Itaqui, Fazenda Itahyê and Cantareira Granites
are virtually indistinguishable considering the uncertainties. A slight age increase in the
westernmost pluton (São Roque Granite) is also suggested by a U-Pb TIMS zircon date
obtained in a rhyolite dike close to its northeast border (607±7 Ma; single concordant
fraction; Hackspacher et al., 2000). The subalkaline and peraluminous granites dated in
this work (samples JP-18, MD-42b and TICO-2) occupy the younger part of this time
range (all with ages ~591-592 Ma), which in the case of the Cantareira Granite sample
MD-42b is in agreement with the field relationships.
The absolute ages obtained in our study contradict the previous notion that the
main period of granite emplacement in the SRD was ~630-620 Ma, based on
unpublished U-Pb TIMS zircon dating of the Cantareira, Itaqui, Tico-Tico (Topfner,
1996) and Barro Branco granites (Ragatky, 1998) and on a Shrimp date of 620±11 Ma
obtained by Tassinari et al. (2010) for the Moinho Granite. In our view, it is difficult to
accept a 20-30 Ma lifetime for a structurally circumscribed pluton, even when it is

As suggested by recent precise dating of classical granite plutons in Sierra Nevada

and intermediate-level crust (Coleman et al., 2004; Metzel et al., 2006).
Zircon crystals showing ages slightly older than the magmatic ages were
identified in some of our samples (CANT-6, TICO-2, JP-18) and interpreted as
antecrysts. However, we did not find any evidence to confirm that the 630-620 Ma dates
obtained by Topfner (1996) correspond to magmatic crystallization ages. The fact that
the same discrepancy between Topfner’s (1996) results and ours is observed in the
small and compositionally homogeneous Tico-Tico granite encourages us to look for
other reasons to explain how the TIMS determinations have resulted in older dates. Our
preferred explanation is that this is due to the incorporation, in the multi-grain zircon
fractions used by that author, of small, undetected inherited cores that had the effect of
slightly “aging” the final result. In fact, inheritance was clearly detected by Topfner in
both his Tico-Tico and Cantareira samples, and care was taken to avoid its influence on
the age estimate. However, as our CL images show, inherited cores, besides being
relatively abundant in some SRD granite samples, may be too small and thus impossible
to be detected or avoided during crystal selection for TIMS analyses, especially when
not supported by CL. These inherited cores are typically of Paleproterozoic to Archean
age, and thus even small volumes may produce non-negligible shifts on the final
integrated TIMS age. This would also be reflected in an increase on the uncertainties of
the final dates, which is indeed observed in all ages reported by Topfner (1996) and
Ragatky (1998), which are above those expected for a precise technique such as TIMS.
6.2. Inferences on sources
6.2.1 Whole-rock geochemistry

abundant in the geological record, but their genesis and tectonic significance are still
very controversial (e.g., Roberts & Clemens, 1993; Chappell et al., 1998 Barbarin,
1999; Clemens et al., 2011; Castro, 2014). In particular, experimental results indicate
that more mafic “granitic” melts are not generated under typical conditions of partial
melting in the continental crust (e.g., Barbarin, 1999). Accordingly, I-type granitic rocks

The SRD HKCA granites are mostly<68% SiO2, and often bear mafic
microgranular enclaves and synplutonic mafic dykes. These are unequivocal signals of
coeval mafic magmatism, but the extent to which these magmas were mixed and
incorporated into the granite magmas is unclear. Negative correlations of P and SiO2
within individual plutons (e.g., Itaqui, Fig. 4) are consistent with apatite saturation over
the whole compositional range and would imply high liquidus temperatures if the
compositions of our granitic rocks with 64-70% SiO2 are close to melts (960-1,000 o C
using the apatite saturation curves of Harrison & Watson, 1984). Zircon saturation
temperatures from our HKCA granites in this silica range are much lower (770-790 o C),
reflecting the zircon-undersaturated character of their parent melts.
Other typical geochemical features of the SRD HKCA granites are the
fractionated REE patterns without negative Eu anomalies, high Sr and high Sr/Y ratios;
collectively, they are indicative that the parent melts were generated at relatively high
pressures, under conditions where plagioclase is unstable and garnet is stable. For
amphibolite protoliths, for instance, “Grt-in” requires minimum pressures of 15 kbar
(Moyen, 2009); this would imply melting in deep and probably thickened crust (e.g.,
Gromet & Silver, 1987), or even offcrust melting (see Castro, 2014).
The peraluminous Tico-Tico Granite has all characteristics of being derived
from a purely crustal magma (e.g. SiO2?70%; peraluminous character; absence of
mafic microgranular enclaves). Its weakly fractionated REE patterns with negative Eu
anomalies and low Sr/Y indicate melting at lower pressure; the protolith is inferred to
have high time-integrated Rb/Sr to account for the high (0.717-0.725) 87

6.2.3. Inferences on sources from Hf and Nd isotopes
The Hf isotope signature of zircon from granites is a powerful tool to study the
source(s) of their parent magmas, but extrapolation of eHf back to the time of protolith
formation is strongly dependent on its (usually unknown) Lu/Hf ratio. This is well
illustrated by the wide spread of depleted mantle “model ages” reported in Table 4.
Zircons have extremely low 176
Lu/ 177
Hf, with mean values typically varying in our
samples from 0.0004 to 0.0008; these ratios usually correlate negatively with the degree
of fractionation of the whole-rock REE patterns, reaching up to one order of magnitude
higher values in the Perus tourmaline granite and in the more radiogenic crystals from
the Itaqui mafic microgranular enclave. A Hf TDMz, extrapolating the zircon 176
Lu/ 177
Hf
back in time, will usually yield ages that are too young and only give a minimum limit
for the crustal residence of Hf in the zircon (Andersen et al., 2002). The use of the
whole-rock Lu/Hf, in a similar way to what is practice with the Sm/Nd isotope system,
can yield more realistic model ages (Hf TDMwr), but may carry comparatively greater
uncertainty. In fact, even though of similar behavior and occupying the same sites in
many minerals, Lu and Hf may be more commonly subject to fractionation compared to
Sm and Nd, especially when minerals such as zircon and garnet control magma
generation or evolution. We notice, anyhow, that Hf TDMwr calculated for our samples
compare well with whole-rock Nd TDM, relative differences varying from +4 to -6%.

from the Itaqui Granite is consistent with the need for a mantle contribution, but it is
still too negative (-10), implying previous mixing with old crust or derivation from an
enriched mantle.

6.3. Tectonic implications
In his classic review paper on granite classification and its links with
geodynamic environments, Barbarin (1999) emphasized that “first of all, a granitoid can
be used as a geodynamic indicator only when it is correctly typed and also precisely
dated. It is also clear that granitoids should not be used alone but in association with
structural data” The reevaluation of the main period of granite magmatism in the SRD
implied by our new in situ U-Pb dating results illustrates this point. In spite of their
structural and compositional characteristics more akin to those of the “post-tectonic”
“Caledonian I-type” granites of Pitcher (1983) recognized in early reviews (Janasi &
Ulbrich, 1991), overlap of ages with supposedly “syn-orogenic” granites from neighbor
domains has led many authors in recent literature to relate the SRD HKCA granites with
a continental arc geodynamic environment. The main age range established in the
present work for these granites (605-595 Ma) allows a temporal correlation with the
“late-orogenic” magmatism in the neighbor Açungui Domain (e.g., Leite et al., 2007),
and is consistent with their emplacement after the metamorphic peak and any known
indications of high-pressure metamorphism (e.g., Reno et al. 2009, Campos Neto &
Caby, 1999). In this sense, the SRD granites can be related to a “post-collisional” or,
more conservatively, a late deformation tectonic setting.
However, this does not imply that the SRD HKCA granites are disconnected
from the voluminous calc-alkaline granite magmatism that immediately preceded them
in the neighbor domains of the Ribeira Belt. Indeed, the main period of batholith
construction in neighbor domains seems just slightly older in the Açungui Domain
(620-610 Ma; Janasi et al., 2001; Leite et al., 2007; Prazeres Filho et al., 2005) and in
the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe (630-620 Ma; Janasi, 1999 etc). Notably, the main granite
type forming these batholiths is equally a high-K calc-alkaline granite, and their
temporal link to convergent tectonics and a magmatic arc environment is unclear at best.

7. Conclusions
In situ U-Pb dating (Shrimp and LA-ICPMS) of the main granite plutons from
the central São Roque Domain indicates that they were all emplaced within a short time
interval (~605-590 Ma) that is ca. 30 Ma younger than suggested by previous literature
data obtained by TIMS. The discrepancy might be related to the presence of small
inherited cores that are difficult to separate and even to detect in multi-grain fractions
used for those TIMS studies.
A few inherited cores dated by in situ techniques have slightly to moderately
discordant ages that are consistent with the age range found in the detrital zircons from
metasediments of the São Roque Domain (1.7-3.3 Ga, with predominance of ~2.1-2.2
Ga). This suggests that the main protoliths for the Neoproterozoic granite magmas can
be equivalent to those inferred for the ~1.75-1.4 Ga SRD detrital metasediments, which
derived from continental sources mainly of Paleoproterozoic age in continental rift and
passive margin environments.
The Hf and Nd isotope signatures of the Neoproterozoic granite magmas,
obtained respectively from zircon in situ and whole-rock analyses, are also consistent
with sources with a prolonged crustal residence. The Hf isotopes, in particular, point to
the predominance of Paleoproterozoic sources which were juvenile at ~2.4-2.5 Ga, and
partially reworked at 2.1-2.2 Ga. However, sources more radiogenic than these at 600
Ma are required to explain the less negative eHf and eNd of several SRD granites,
especially those of peraluminous and subalkaline character. Inherited cores from the
Tico-Tico leucogranite reveal that these sources could correspond to juvenile crust
accreted during the ~1.75 Ga rifting event that initiated the deposition of the
supracrustal sequences or even during the latest (~2.1 Ga) events recorded in the SF
craton. Such sources are unexposed and were not detected in the detrital zircon
assemblage of the SRD metasediments.
Although not apparent from the Hf-Nd isotope signatures, a Neoproterozoic
juvenile (mantle-derived) component may be present, at least in the more primitive
granites, which show field evidence of mingling with basic melts and are too mafic to

Supplementary File 1. Analytical Methods
1. Whole-rock major and trace-element analyses
X-ray Fluorescence was used to determine the major, minor and trace elements in whole
rock samples. Large samples typically weighing 6-8 kg were broken into pieces of
about 3-5 cm using hammer or hydraulic press, and then were crushed to fragments with
an average size of 1.5 cm with a jaw breaker of Mn-steel. The material was then split in
a cross-type Jones splitter, yielding 100-150 g sub-samples representative of the starting
material. The sub-samples were then milled for 15 minutes on a Pulverisette-type
planetary agate mill. This overall time is usually enough for the material to reach a
particle size smaller than 200 mesh.
Analyses were performed in a Phillips PW2400 spectrometer at the NAP-Geonalitica,
Instituto de Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo, Brazil, following the protocol
described in Mori et al. (1999). Major and minor elements were analyzed from molten
tablets obtained from 1g sample and 9 g of a mixture of spectroscopic grade lithium
tetra and metaborate at 1100-1200 o C in a platinum crucible, using a Claisse fusion
machine. Trace elements were analyzed from pressed pellets obtained from
homogenization of the pulverized sample (previously micronized in a McCrone
Micronizer) and pressing to 30 ton. with wax. Analytical quality was controlled using a
reference material granite JG-1a from Geological Survey of Japan as an unknown
sample, and duplicated samples. The values obtained should be within 2s of the
certified values, and the duplicated samples within 1% of variation.
Rare earth and other trace elements were determined by ICPMS in a Thermo-Analitica
ICAP quadrupode analyzer at the NAP-Geonalitica, Instituto de Geociências,
Universidade de São Paulo, Brazil, following the protocol described in Navarro et al
(2008).
Approximately 40mg of rock powder with grain size<200 mesh were placed in a Teflon
capsule Parr bomb and added with 5 ml of nitric acid and 15 ml of HF, both sub boiling
distillates. The material is heated to 200 o C in an electric oven, under pressure, for five
days. The material is then cooled and transferred to a PFAbeaker where the solution is
heated in hot plate; in this process, SiF4 is eliminated by evaporation. After drying, the
material is dissolved and transferred to a plastic bottle where weights were adjusted to
100g with 1% HNO3. Analytical quality control was checked by the analyses of
reference materials JG-1a and JR-1 as unknown samples, blank and duplicate of some
samples. The values obtained should be within 2s of the certified values, and the
duplicated samples within 1% of variation (Navarro et al, 2008).
2. Whole rock Nd and Sr isotope ratios
Rb-Sr isotopic analyses of whole rock samples were performed at CPGeo, Instituto de
Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo, Brazil, following the protocols described by
Sato et al (2008). The attack of the samples is similar to that used for ICP-MS, the main
difference is the greater digestion time (10 days at 160 ° C) in a Parr bomb. Element
separation in columns loaded with cation exchange resin AG-50W-X8 (200-400mesh)
used deionized water and sub-boiling HCl in varying concentrations. Sr extraction was
performed with 2.5N HCl, and the residue of this phase was washed with 6.2N HCl for

3. Zircon concentration, mounting and cathodoluminescence study
The separation and concentration of zircon consists of crushing, grinding, sieving,
vibrating table, electromagnetic separation, heavy liquids and finally manual picking.
The routine used at CPGeo is described by Sato et al (2014) and consists of the
following steps: a) rock samples (0.5 to 3 kg for granites and ~ 20 kg for mafic rocks) is
crushed in a jaw crusher; b) crushed material is screened to separate a fraction of 100-
250 mesh particle size, using a disk mill and a battery of sieves; c) the separated fraction
is taken to a vibratory table to concentrate heavy minerals; d) magnetic minerals are
removed with a hand magnet; e) minerals with different magnetic susceptibilities are
concentrated in a Frantz-type magnetic separator, by varying the inclination and the
intensity of the electromagnetic field; f) the least magnetic fractions are passed
successively into bromoform (d = 2.85 g/cm 3 ) and methylene iodide (d= 3.2 g/cm
3 ) to
further concentrate the heavy minerals of interest. Any remaining sulfides present in the
concentrates are eliminated with HCl or HNO3. About 50-100 zircon grains are
separated by hand picking with the aid of a magnifying microscope, and then mounted
on double sided adhesive tape and embedded in epoxy-typeresin. The mount is then
polished to expose the fresh surface of the grain trapped in the resin.
A previous study of cathodoluminescence (CL) of each of the samples was necessary to
choose the proper position of the spot during the in situ analyses by Shrimp or LA-
ICPMS. After a thin layer of gold cover (2-3nm) was added to the mounts, these images
were obtained in a FEI Quanta 250 SEM spectrometer with a XMAX CL detector
(Oxford Instruments). Operating conditions were: high voltage, 15 kV, distance, 16.9-
17 mm, PMD detector, range of magnification, 95-250x.

4. U-Pb geochronology by Shrimp and ELA-ICPMS
Part of the U-Pb zircon dating was performed in the SHRIMP IIe equipment installed at
CPGeo, Instituto de Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo. The Shrimp is a mass
spectrometer coupled to a high resolution ion microprobe that uses a collimated and
accelerated beam of primary ions (O2) to reach a target where secondary ions are
generated from 30 mm spots. The secondary ions are accelerated through the equipment
and the isotopes generated by the sample, 254
UO +, 206
Pb+, 207
Pb+, 208
Pb+, 238
U + and + 254
ThO and 196
Zr2O + , are measured successively. The corrections required by the
technique are made by the analyses of unknown materials and reference materials with
known isotopic ratios (matrix-matched) for determining specific calibration factors
(Black et al, 2004). 12-16 spot analyses from each of the unknown zircon samples are
performed according to the method described in Sato et al (2014). During the run every
5 determinations analyzed the Temora-2 reference material (estimated age 416.78 ±
0.33 Ma; Black et al, 2004) is used as 206
Pb/ 238
U age reference, for calculation of
common Pb correction factors and fractionation factors. Common lead corrections
usually use 204
Pb according to Stacey and Kramer (1975). Reference material SL13
(238 ppm) is used as U composition reference. Data are reduced with SQUID 1.6
software (Ludwig, 2009) and ISOPLOT 4 (Ludwig, 2003) has been used for treatment
of data to estimate ages and generate diagrams.
The determinations by ELA-ICPMS (Excimer Laser Ablation - ICPMS) were also held
on the premises of CPGeo, Instituto de Geociências, USP and used the Excimer Laser
pulsed 193nm ArF (Photon Machine) with operating conditions 6 mJ, 8.55 J/cm 2
(100%), 6 Hz and 32 mm spot. The ablated material was carried through an Ar and He
flow of 0.9 L/min to a HR-ICPMS multicollector spectrometer, Neptune model from
Thermo-Finnigan, operated at 926W. A mixed configuration of Faraday collectors for
readings in Volts and ion multipliers (MIC's) for readings in cps allowed to obtain
simultaneous measurements of 204
Pb, 206
Pb, 207
Pb, 208
Pb, 232
Th, 238
U, 204
Hg and 202
Hg.
The signal obtained for each of the isotopes is integrated over 60 s laser ablation at each
point analyzed. Two worksheets were obtained with 13 determinations each,
interspersed by 2 analyses of blank for 204
Pb correction, 2 determinations of zircon
reference material GJ-1 (estimated 206
Pb/ 238
U age of 599.8±4.5 Ma; Jackson et al, 2004)
to correction of the U/Pb and Th/U ratios and 2 determinations of Nist-612 for
correction of the 204
Pb/ 206
Pb ratio.
5. Hf isotope analyses in zircon by LA-ICPMS
Zircon Hf isotope analyses were performed using a HR-ICPMS multicollector
spectrometer, Neptune model from Thermo-Finnigan attached to ArF Excimer Laser
193 nm (Photon Machine) with operating conditions 6 mJ, 8.55 J/cm 2 (100%), 7 Hz and
47 mm spot size. The ablated material was loaded into the plasma operated at 1000 W,
through an Ar flow of 0.5 L/ min, 0.25 L/min of He and 1.2 L/min of N2.The collector
configuration allowed simultaneous measurements of the isotopic ratios 173
Yb/ 171

Hf/ 177

Lu/ 177

Hf/ 177
Hf. The measured values of the 176
Hf/ 177

the GJ-1 reference material were 0.282063±0.000293 (N= 4, 2s), in agreement with the
value 0.282000±0.000004 by Morel et al. (2008). The results were processed in Excel
spreadsheet using the 176
